channel.title: Wickerbox
channel.description: Adventures of an aerospace geek in Portland, Oregon.

item.title: ISO Shutter Speed Example
item.description:
This is a shutter speed example using an X100S in snow at Tualatin Wildlife Refuge on Sunday, February 9th, 2014.

I wanted to get a sense for ISO, aperture, exposure time, and brightness of the resulting image. All photos were taken with +2 EV exposure bias with the mode on auto. I didn’t control for aperture. The results make sense because as the shutter is open longer, more light is captured.

ISO: 1/4000
Brightness: 9.75
Aperture: F2
Shutter Speed: 1/4096s = 244 microseconds

ISO: 1/2000s
Brightness: 9.94
Aperture: F2.8
Shutter Speed: 1/2048s = 488 microseconds

ISO: 1/1000s
Brightness: 9.87
Aperture: F4
Shutter Speed: 1/1024s = 976 microseconds

ISO: 1/500s
Brightness: 9.86
Aperture: F4.9
Shutter Speed: 1/512s = 1.95 milliseconds

ISO: 1/250s
Brightness: 9.74
Aperture: F7.2
Shutter Speed: 1/250s = 4 milliseconds

ISO: 1/125s
Brightness: 9.7
Aperture: F9.8
Shutter Speed: 1/128s = 7.81 milliseconds

ISO: 1/60s
Brightness: 9.52
Aperture: F13
Shutter Speed: 1/64s = 15.6 milliseconds

ISO: 1/30s
Brightness: 9.4
Aperture: F16
Shutter Speed: 1/32s = 31.25 milliseconds

ISO: 1/15s
Brightness: 9.4
Aperture: F16
Shutter Speed: 1/16s = 62.5 milliseconds

ISO: 1/8s
Brightness: 9.32
Aperture: F16
Shutter Speed: 1/8s = 125 milliseconds

ISO: 1/4s
Brightness: 9.54
Aperture: F16
Shutter Speed: 1/4s = 250 milliseconds

ISO: 1/2s
Brightness: 9.54
Aperture: F16
Shutter Speed: 1/2s = 500 milliseconds

item.title: Exposure Example
item.description:
This is an exposure example using an X100S in snow at Tualatin Wildlife Refuge on Sunday, February 9th, 2014.

I wanted to get a sense for ISO, aperture, exposure time, and brightness of the resulting image when stepping from -2 to +2 EV exposure bias with the mode on auto. I didn’t control for aperture. I didn’t control for anything, really, I’m just playing around. The results make sense because as the shutter is open longer, more light is captured.

ISO: 1/950s
Brightness: 8.94
Aperture: F11
Shutter Speed: 1/969s = 1.03 milliseconds
Exposure Bias: -2 EV

ISO: 1/850s
Brightness: 8.79
Aperture: F8
Shutter Speed: 1/873s = 1.14 milliseconds
Exposure Bias: -1 EV

ISO: 1/900s
Brightness: 8.83
Aperture: F5.7
Shutter Speed: 1/891s = 1.12 milliseconds
Exposure Bias: 0 EV

ISO: 1/640s
Brightness: 9.37
Aperture: F5.7
Shutter Speed: 1/648s = 1.54 milliseconds
Exposure Bias: +1 EV

ISO: 1/450s
Brightness: 9.87
Aperture: F5.7
Shutter Speed: 1/458s = 2.18 milliseconds
Exposure Bias: +2 EV

item.title: 124km DxWifi Flight Test
item.description:
The antenna setup in the back of the plane. We were all about all these different ways to attach the antenna, internally and externally, but it turned out taping it in the back window was good enough.

Taxiing out and taking off at Troutdale.

Looking northeast towards Camas.

Our most excellent pilot.

Our most excellent antenna operator.

We did a few circles on the Washington side of the river to give the Rocky Butte ground team a chance to get up and running ot see if they could catch our packets. We had no idea if we were going to even be able to make contact.

But we did! And we headed north to the west of Mt St Helens.

We warned the ground team we might lose them for a minute or two and we took a detour to check out the caldera.

We ended up spending a lot of time circling over Morton, WA, but that was about where our signal problems started. We did continue on to Kapowsin Field, right at the edge of Seattle airspace, at about 10,000 feet.

On the way back south, we moved the antenna to the front right window but we couldn’t shake the communication problems. We lost both SMS and radio to Rocky Butte so when we turned around the ground team wasn’t entirely sure where we were and we weren’t ever really able to re-establish contact. The antennas have a very narrow beam over which they can receive so if we had to be exactly where the Rocky Butte team was pointing their antenna, and for the most part we weren’t.

We were also considering fuel/range issues and ended up deciding to just head back to Troutdale and call it a win.

On final to Troutdale, with bonus propellers. (It’s actually not really possible with iPhone to take a picture out the front window that doesn’t catch the prop.)

Our pilot puts the plane away.

item.title: Oven Control Board v2
item.description:
I worked with Tung as part of the ME capstone team at Portland State to update the oven controller Arduino shield I made last week. Tung had already updated the Eagle schematic so this time for me it was just layout, routing, and basic soldering. I fixed the one via problem but then promptly made the same mistake on the other set of headers, so I delivered the board last night and it should work fine but the soldering was trickier than I’d like.

I’m still so spoiled by having OSHPark. The only Gerbers I give our lab’s LPKF router are the Top Layer, Bottom Layer, Board Outline, and Unplated Drill. No silkscreen. I could solder mask but I haven’t. Maybe next time. I used materials and headers I had on hand but even through OSHPark it’d be just under $30 for three boards.

Here are the schematic, layout, and final photos. Eagle files are on the Github repo.

item.title: Oven Control Board v1
item.description:
An ME capstone team at Portland State is working on an oven so we can cure our own composites. It’s awesome. This oven control board was a five-day project that came out of nowhere this week on Tuesday and which I delivered on Sunday.

Tung, their electrical person, already had the design figured out and working with breadboard components and an Arduino. What he really wanted was an Arduino shield so we met, looked at what he had, and figured out how we’d put it on the right footprint. This is the first time I’d been able to sit with someone who was new to Eagle and really explain what makes a decent schematic, so it’s pretty cool to see how much I’ve learned in just a couple of years.

The layout was constrained by the shield but even moreso by our plan to use the LPKF router. It had to be a two-layer board that didn’t have plated through-holes or vias. I managed to put all the traces except one on the bottom layer because all the components get soldered on the bottom side (they’re all through-hole) and then I just made that a much wider polygon fill and dropped vias to get the top-trace signal connected down below.

Unfortunately, Arduino shields sit on top of the Arduino so I had to drop an extra via on each pad of the 0.1" headers so copper wire could be slid through and squashed, essentially plating them myself.

The final product doesn’t look too shabby. Well, I take that back — the isolation on the LPKF is so tiny (even at the double-width!) that I’m terrified of putting too much solder on each pin and shorting it outside the pad. This is really crappy soldering but I ohmed everything out so electrically the joints are fine.

Definitely I’ve been spoiled with OSHPark and $5/sq in board with plated through-holes and solder mask.

The libraries and everything are all up in the oven-controller Github repo.
